segments.text: I'm talking with Michael Zinman in Yonkers, New York.
Is this where we are?
Arsley, New York.
Arsley.
I thought we were in Yonkers.
We're in Arsley, New York.
Oh, you were teasing me.
We're in Arsley, New York.
I can grab some of this food, right?
We're having a lovely lunch in a room that I described on the way in.
It looks kind of like a CIA safe house.
Well, it is.
It's a house where you keep your books, I guess.
Or some of them.
Some of them.
Let's start with you and start with a couple of screen buffs.
Tell me a little bit about yourself, how the man who runs earthworm and becomes a passionate collector of American inference.
Not accustomed as I am to being paid.
I have always been surrounded with books and had an opportunity as a kid to have access to a bookseller or, let me back it up, a refugee cousin
My family came out of Germany in the late 1930s.
A brilliant guy.
And he wanted to be a teacher, but his English was no good.
He couldn't speak English, but it was too guttural German.
He had a knowledge of, I guess, rare books and books, and he became an Italian bookseller.
His name was Walter Ganz.
And he wound up living a block away from us, my family, as I grew up.
I mean, the guy was a prick, but I was probably the only person who ever had access to his library or to his house or had any interest in him.
Because of that, I at least had a passing knowledge of what books were.
I had some idea of the
How do you want to put it?
The form of the book, both physical and intellectual.
The book as object and the book as object .
It's something of value.
At the time, I used to collect
How old were you?
This was, let's say, my late teens, my teens, you know, high school.
You're a New Yorker, right?
New Yorker.
City?
Monkers.
But I used to, my mother used to go to auctions, local auctions and what I loved.
Did she collect?
She was in some sense, but not a book collector.
Not a book collector, but she would collect, you know, tchotchkes and things and art, and she had a fairly good eye.
What is this brand like?
Mozzarella, fresh mozzarella.
It was made about an hour before we bought it.
I used to hang around the auctions, and I started buying prints.
I'm going to buy some nice prints, you know, early and what have you.
And I would buy books occasionally without any concept of what I was buying, except if they were old or not new, and they were a quarter or whatever.
At some point, I decided I wanted... I got interested in Audubon.
as it was.
I don't know why, but I saw some Audubon prints, folio prints of the quadrupeds, mainly the rafts, and I could buy them for like five bucks a piece.
And I was essentially angry at the fact that this gorgeous stuff was so cheap.
I started buying... But is your background bookish?
Did you read a lot?
Oh, yeah.
Yeah.
Well, it was curious.
My background was curious.
was quite curious.
Well, professionally, did you describe yourself as a businessman?
No, I was an engineer.
I mean, I studied engineering in Cornell.
What year did you graduate?
I didn't.
This is off the record.
I was invited to leave
And the deal was, if I left and didn't register the next term, they wouldn't try to prosecute me for grand theft.
I stole all the toilet seats in the university the day before the alumni came up.
They were very upset.
They were smiling.
Do you remember the pleasure or you had a reverberation?
No, I remember nothing bad.
The only time I've ever been...
The only time I've ever been embarrassed, and that's something I will tell you about, is with something that I wound up at the HRC.
That's a wonderful story.
I really would like the HRC story.
I will.
Anyway.
Of course, it's not only what I tell it to you, it's ongoing and continuing.
Okay.
Let me also say, parenthetically, that Mel Ellestine, you know, I told him, he applied for the HRC job, but he gave it to Tom Staley, and then he got to get it yet.
Is this... When we get to it, I will give you the true quote to that story that you will regale, you will be omniscient knowing what I'm going to tell you.
You think so?
Okay.
You're going to love it.
Okay.
You put all this stuff together, right?
Yeah, we wouldn't buy that.
So...
Now, this is not pepperoni.
This is like a cappuccola?
What is it?
Yeah, it's not cappuccola.
It's a soprassata.
Anyway, they make it right there.
Wonderful.
It's not particularly hot today, though.
Anyway, so I started getting interested in Portugan prints.
Must have been around 1958, 59.
And I wanted to buy, I suddenly bought up on Quadra Pets.
And the first books I ever bought that were collectible books, I went to an auction of the Sintas sale, Oscar Benjamin Sintas.
Didn't know what the hell it was.
I bought two books.
They were cheap, 25 bucks.
And I think I was in college at the time.
And I would think the sale was probably 56 or 57.
But I still have one of them.
But shortly thereafter, I started finding out about Audubon and his work.
Why do you have such a ... I've got to type this, so I don't want to say it.
Why do you have such a fascination for Audubon?
I didn't.
But, no, you mentioned him at least three or four times now.
Well, this started, you asked me how I got into the collecting.
There's an aspect of collecting that has to do, in the beginning, with... Keep going, this is not very good, I just want to get it.
concepts of, let's say, value.
Concepts of value.
My feeling is that people who are collectors, who have advanced states of the disease, are incapable of not

using their eyes to measure value in abstract or relative terms, whatever it may be, whether it's a woman's body, whether it's a car, whether it's a picture on the wall, whether it's the price of a meal, whatever it is, there is a type of mentality, a type of mindset that if you say to me, for example,
I just bought this tie for five bucks.
Somehow or other, I will immediately register.
I'm incapable of not registering somewhere in my mind mechanism.
You paid too much, you paid the right price, or you got a bargain.
It was undervalued.
It doesn't matter whatever it may be.
It's a totally unfocused mechanism, but it's there all the time.
You measure value.
And I think that true collectors at some point go through this and are constantly defining what is value, what is the nature of collecting, why do you
go out and fund $25,000 for a fucking book like Moby Dick, okay?
So when somebody copied without the title page and invoiced it to me, one ragged dick.
But I'm saying, why do you go and spend $25,000 for a book?
What is it in the human...
mind, makeup, that people who don't have illimitable funds, because illimitable funds corrupt or take away the pleasure of discretionary choice of money.
When you have something that you're willing to shell out,
It's just the amount of money for it.
Or you have a shelf of books in there that's three feet wide.
It's worth more than your house.
And you're not a guy who's got 50 or 500 million dollars.
You're a guy who's making a living.
And who comes?
What?
We got two.
There's a cup in the cabinet.
You can wash it out in the toilet.
point that I'm getting at is why do people spend money?
I'm getting off on a very... I also think that, you know, we can be vague about this, but I don't think that there are bad results and means, however.
But even so, my means are relatively... Yes, that's true.
Yes, but my means are still relatively limited.
Certainly, they are far more precarious than many other people, and I, you know,
But that's irrelevant.
Oh, I think it's relevant.
The means of this, okay?
Have you ever gone hungry because of purchasing books?
Oh, sure.
Sure.
I once, when I was, I remember at one time there was a... Absolutely.
Well, that's it.
Yeah, I'm curious.
You actually went hungry.
You actually deprived yourself of some human need.
Well, let me tell you the story, okay?
When I was first married, my wife was working as a teacher, and I was struggling, trying to get a business going.
And there used to be, I lived in my plans at the time, and there was a thrift shop, Federated Jewish, a thrift shop or something.
And they had a painting.
I used to buy crap there, nice things, but they had a painting on the wall, a painting they wanted 100 bucks for.
So I offered them, I think at the time, 15 dollars.
And they laughed, and they said, no, blah, blah, blah.
Got a glass?
So I kept going back, because I was on the way home from work.
I used to drive in, I used to take the train home and what have you, and I'd go by.
And for six months, the price was $100.
Then they finally dropped it to $75.
And after about a year, they were dropped at $5 and $10 a week or a month or what have you.
I finally walked in there one day, and they said, Mr. Zimmer,
Finally, you got it.
I said, I'll give you $10.
And they wouldn't sell it.
So I was thinking about it.
I was going down to my... Did you buy it for the $15?
No.
I said, I'll give you $10.
Did you give me $15 a year ago?
Anyway, that weekend, I'm going down to visit my parents.
I'm with my wife.
I stopped off there.
I decide I'll pay the $15 or what have you.
I go in and I buy the pension for $15.
I put it in the car.
My wife says, what did you do?
I said, I just bought this painting.
And she became hysterical.
She said, we have a disconnect notice from the phone.
We have a dispossessed notice from the landlord.
We're three months behind in our rent.
We can't pay our phone.
We can't pay our rent.
We can't pay our electricity.
We can't.
And you're buying paintings?
I said, yeah.
It was cruel.
So yeah.
Nice painting.
It was OK.
I still got it.
That was my next question.
What is it?
A pleasant painting.
My daughter likes it.
I'll give it to her.
An American painting?
Probably.
It's a nondescript painting.
It's a pretty painting.
Is it a pastoral scene?
It's a pastoral scene.
Winter scene of trees.
Me too.
But what I'm getting at is, sure, I'll spend money for books.
I'll spend money.
I've spent hundreds of thousands of dollars

books but to buy a car oh yes hmm at what point did you did you to do it's like the guy who wakes up one day and says i am an alcoholic i'm going through the process um the i know something at what point did you say i'm i'm really possessed i'm obsessed i am driven
When did I admit it?
When did I admit it to myself?
I was doing something quite irrational.
When did I admit it to myself, or when did I admit it to myself verbally irrational?
Well, whatever.
I'd kind of like to know anything about the process.
Okay.
The process is this.
When I started... It's hard to really, I think, to focus or to...

identify that with me but i think it was why because it was an evolutionary sort of thing because there were other competition it was competitive there were competitive demands okay there's competitive demands for time space and money wives um friends uh family or food
You say white, that's plural, I guess.
No, it's the... Well, yes.
Yes, thank you.
Anyway, the point I'm getting at is that... Well, I would just ask that question.
I've talked to people who have lost families because of the obsession of the book.
Of course, it does have a reason.
I'm just trying to find out how often you've been married or how long you've been married.
You did tell me an anecdote about a painting and the wife went crazy over the, you know... Yeah, but she's still my wife.
Well, there you have it.
That's good.
That's an understanding of the wife.
Yeah, you betcha she's understanding.
Anyway, he's my father.
Father's my daughter.
He's also at Leavelin.
You met the wife?
No, I didn't met the wife.
Look, I started collecting art before I started collecting books.
Then I continued to collect art and collect books.
Then I continued to collect a little more books than art.
Then, when I was collecting books, the evolution of me, of my collection, my focus, went from
the idea of Audubon and the anger that Audubon's animals were underappreciated.
I was angry that I could buy a painting or a folio print of Audubon for five bucks.
Because it was a rat.
Then I started asking, where were the originals of all of these things?
Because what you have, you know, the original that they're talking about is a print.
Where are the originals?
Then I started looking around to try to buy the original studies

natural history and i started buying some of those and that sort of you know competed with uh my desire to buy books you know you buy a painting the painting's a good answer much more so you know you're going to buy now as it turned out as far as i was dealing i'm sure a little light is flicking okay let's not look
It's flicking.
It's flicking.
Anyway, I went from collecting Audubon to collecting natural history as a general focus.
You can always buy a few books here or there because you're a junkie anyway.
I then decided I wanted to collect American natural history because I found a good reference to it by maximizing over the book on American natural history references.
And I started getting rid of my European natural history and collecting more and more money.
Getting rid of how?
Selling.
I'd sell to dealers who I could then buy.
Did you take a loss?
No, I generally made a lot of money.
As a collector, I have made a great deal of money in my books.
That's very interesting.
Most collectors get screwed.
Most collectors collect for different reasons than I do.
I would say to you that
The collectors who collect for reasons other than prestige generally are extremely successful in measuring.
If one measures success by you make money when you sell it, whether you deal it or do other things with it,
The people who collect books with some reason not to flip them for a profit or with some focus to what they're collecting and some knowledge, it's time and grade.
I spent a lot of time and a lot of money and a lot of effort collecting books.
If I measure the value of my time economically,
that I spend with my books, my book collection costs me a lot of money.
If my income is arbitrarily, as an employee, quarter of a million dollars a year, and I spend 50% of my time... Well, you're not an employee, you're not a company.
It doesn't matter.
I don't own the company, but I'm an editor of the company, but it's still a book.
If my value, my professional value is this, then
If I spend 50% of my time with books, then I have to add to the cost of what I buy the alternate value of my time.
So that people who tell you that if I buy so many books or so many dollars, you have corporate overhead.
One could impute this sort of value, but that's the pleasure of living.

But still in all, what I was getting at is that when I got done collecting, or when I started to shift in area of collecting, I generally was able to dispose of what I collected at a significant profit.
Mainly through dealers?
Yes.
That's pretty good, because dealers will factor in their own markup.
Mainly through dealers.
And I would give a dealer, I mean, Quaritch, for example,
I used to go into one side of Quark and give them my natural history books and go to the other side and buy them out of Americana.
So you go to London to buy books, do you think?
I have quite often.
Regularly.
Could buy American in France?
Yeah.
I don't go to Paris to buy American in London.
Although now, most of them, it's very inefficient to do it.
I wasn't buying American imprints necessarily, I was buying natural history.
So I'm buying natural history.
Then I switched over to American natural history.
Then I switched over to voyages and travels.
Which is really a lovely thing.
Commenting on natural history.
I picked up your cook stuff.
I mean, I've had Columbus letters.
Yeah, I got rid of them.
What happened was, I went from autobahn to natural history, to American natural history, to voyages and travels commenting on natural history,
The voyages and travels in Americana to the New World.
Did this reflect changes in your life?
No, just to... Changes in your intellectual development?
Did this reflect changes in interest?
Did you become void with earlier things?
To some degree, yes.
There's other areas... All of the above.
Yes, to a degree.
They were all less than satisfying or continuing to be satisfying over a long period of time.
One of the other factors that came into play is that if you anticipate a market...
or an area of interest, then you buy at a certain level.
If other people... Maybe before the interest is there.
Whatever, whatever.
Being precocious, in other words.
Determining... Opportunistic.
I started buying natural history, let's say, when natural history was ignored.
Now, so long as it was ignored, you get into a situation where you're willing to pay certain chips for certain things.
Now, if I was buying... Certain chips?
Yeah, economic chips, units, or whatever you want to call it.
If I'm buying quadruple... My type is chips, and it's C-H-I-P-N.
If I buy, if I'm collecting, and one of the things I did was I always collected multiple.
One of the ways I've always looked or moved into an area of collecting is I've always wanted action, as opposed to quality.
Quality.
I wanted quality instead of quality.
You know what I was saying when I said quality?
Yeah.
That's how we got.
I know.
Anyway, but I'm saying to you, I wanted quality instead of quality.
And I wanted to handle... Okay, the difference is this, that I believe collecting is an educated process.
And one of the satisfying ways of dealing with it is handling things.
You've got to handle the goods.
If you handle it tactically, objectively, you know, visually, you learn to discriminate between...
Factorily.
Mole factorily.
Mole factorily too.
Smell it.
You betcha.
I can let you smell some shit I'd want too.
To me, I think that's interject.
A woman wrote a book about the senses and a guy went blind.
He loved his book.
Story about that in the Times today.
It was an article.
Okay.
Today's book review.
Oh, well, the book on the... Some woman, some cunt.
Yeah, she's wonderful.
She let a bat go through her hair or something like that?
Let me ask you.
But anyway, she told me about this guy who went blind, loved his books.
He learned to identify every book in the library by smell.
Is that a great story?
Is that a great story?
It's not a bad story, is it?
I'm just going to get in my book, I can tell you that.
Go ahead, I'm sorry.
I don't even know where we were, but that was my mistake.
Interview was there.
We're talking about a focus of collecting.
Some collectors are passive collectors and want to have form for them a collection, neat, fastidious, and elegant, which is fine.
These are collections.
I guess what I'm drawing again, I don't mean to interrupt, but...
I want to know what you get out of the collection personally.
Do you know it?
Do you feel it?
Do you read it?
Do you absorb it?
What does it do for you other than acquisition and possession?
Okay.
I have no possessive instinct.
I don't believe it.
I have no possessive instinct.
Let's identify him if it's all right.
William Miller, a pedagogue.
I mean, you say this knowing him.
You say he is not possessive in any way.
But the man is a biblio maniac.
Big difference.
I don't... You said he is a preservationist and a compiler.
And we don't believe, therefore, we need to collect it as well.
No, not possessive.
Possessive.
You say possessive.
You see.
Possessive.
I have a sense of my book.
This is my book.
This is not my book.
Possessive.
This is something that I'm using at the time.
You are a custodian?
Yeah.
Passing along.
But not simply a custodian.
The process.
Do I ever go over the hill?
No!
William Miller.
How do you know Michael?
I'm just curious.
We met at a bookshop.
I was looking to buy a building.
But you seem to have an understanding of the book for us.
No, I'll tell you an excellent story that describes both ends of what we're talking about.
You seem to have some insight.
I'm standing in a bookshop in Hastings.
I'm looking across the street at a building that is for sale, talking to the owner of the shop where I'm social.
We are talking about what this building is worth and if it's worth doing.
It's like a 10-unit building or something like that.
As I'm standing there with my hands in my pocket, a guy walks up to me, stands next to me, looks at the building, looks at me, looks at the building, says, Hey, what do you think?
do a little of this, do a little of that.
I'd make some money on it.
You got the money?
I said, no, I don't have the money.
My name is Zinman, come and see me.
That's how it started.
Out there, in the universe at present, there are littered remains of the course of human events.
Some people come along and curry

those littered remains specialities they farm when you're finished farming and you harvest yourself sometimes you eat sometimes you keep often you sell that's what this process is in this case to a great degree there's a little of this there's a little of that there's a little of that
Until you put it together.
Then once it is together, then it becomes appreciated.
Those parts are greater than less.
How long have you known Michael?
Ten years, 12 years, 15 years.
You studied him?
You studied him?
It sounded like you studied him.
Not as a laboratory animal.
I mean, as an example of human behavior.
I know him.
But I don't think that's unique to Michael.
There are many collectors.
But there are many collectors like that.
Collector dealers, that's the difference.
I mean, before you were talking about collectors, you were talking about people I've never known, and I know a lot of book people.
These seem to be... Oh, Colin Franklin is a collector dealer.
Yeah.
All the bookmen are collector dealers.
This didn't get on the tape.
I said, Leonard, he's showing these collectors.
I said, why did you sell them?
And I said, he goes like this and says, that's nothing going on the tape.
He says, money.
The point is this, that for whatever compelling reason I have to collect
It's not to possess.
Possessing is irrelevant.
It's the action.
Well, Vic Manning says he gave up gambling to collect.
Quote.
He said he loved the baccarat games, he loved the table games, and he was a heavy gambler.
This guy had an interview with John Larroquette.
He gave up booze to become a collector.
So it was kind of like taking one passion and kind of making it more productive.
This is not what I'm suggesting that you've done in any way like that.
Look, like every other messianic asshole, you look for a cause that is just.
I simply, being a collector and accumulating and having the fun, the pleasure that I got was in the act of collecting.
The hunt?
Yeah.
the treasure hunting, just the fun of collecting.
The possessing of the book, as pleasurable as it is, is transitory.

I have, if I'm no longer active, I had probably the, I collected at one time stamps, and the stamps that I collected were revenue stamps, tax paid revenues, and I had a very formidable collection, probably the best collection of beer stamps, of tax paid beer stamps around, and I loved them.
When I decided that books were overwhelming this area of my interest, I didn't pack them away.
I dumped them.
Because if it wasn't alive, I wasn't locking it up and putting it away.
Let me address an apparent contradiction.
Apparent.
And it only goes back to something we were talking about, which I'll raise, and then we can discuss both of you.
You mentioned, as we were talking, that you probably own the finest collections anywhere outside of an institution of American interests.
Is that a fair statement?
Yes.
Certainly the largest.
Okay.
And certainly the most important.
Well, maybe you haven't.
That's not necessarily the finest.
Okay.
Well, what's the difference?
I look at finest as... Fine, I don't mean in terms of condition.
I look at fine in terms of quality, condition, significance.
Now, I don't own, for example, I don't think I own many of the great high spots of American imprints.
I don't have a Bay Songbook.
I don't have a 1648.
It is 13 or 11th.
I don't have a 1648 Cambridge platform.
I got two 1671 Cambridge platforms and four 1680 Cambridge platforms, but the 16471s are all defective in some way.
Is that just you all right?
No.
Not at all.
But there are many people who have, for example, beautiful copies of the Eliot Bible.
Why don't you point out parenthetically that you own three Elliott Bibles?
I own three Elliott Bibles, but I own three second editions, only half of the first edition.
So if you were to have a want list, I don't know if you have a want list, a first Elliott Bible will be yours.
Oh, sure, but only I can buy one tomorrow, but I don't want to spend 400 grand for it.
What would you pay for it?
Between you and me?
I would probably, if it was perfect,
I probably wouldn't be a buyer.
No, I probably wouldn't be a buyer because I think that the premium that it would take to get a perfect copy would be something that I wouldn't want to spend.
But if it was lacking a couple of leaves, I'd like to buy one for about a hundred, a hundred and a quarter.
I'm told that conditions of importance is not essential to you.
Yes, you could say that.
I mean, if you buy things that other people might ask,
Because it is not the... Less and less.
Not that I won't continue to buy them, but less and less that other people will pass.
The idea of perfect or less than perfect in the book business was very much irrationally ascribed to the business of pregnant or not pregnant.
They were absolutes.
And whatever basis the booksellers chose to implicate this in the industry or in the area of collectors,
They successfully did it.
If a book was worth $1,000, the same book, you know, in fine condition, the same book lacking the leaf, the last leaf, for example, was worth $75.
You see much of this today in American fiction, modern American fiction.
Let's check.
Not only dust jackets, but condition.
You take a book that's in vogue, for example, The Murphy's Falcon.
A first edition without a dust jacket today is probably going to be on the market for, I would say, $600 to $1,000.
In poor condition, it's probably $75, or fair condition.
In poor condition, it's $25.
But people read these things.
They're not meant to be treasured and strode.
And the same thing when you have a dust jacket that's worth, you know, seven grand, ten grand, or what have you.
That's irrational.
It's not irrational, but it is a premium that I'm not prepared to pay because I have finite sums of money to buy in a universe that will consume my money.
Would you pay a book for a book for it?
Oh, sure.
So what?
But others would pay a lot more.
I'd like to buy it for like $35.
I mean, the Elliott Bible I bought, I bought three Elliott Bibles, one at auction and two from dealers.
And the last one I bought, I bought this year, and it cost me $8,500.
And it's a wonderful and instructive story about the book world.
The book was brought to the California Book Fair.
And the dealer called me up Sunday night after he came back from the fair and said, would you be interested?
You know, would you have been interested?
Would you have been interested in an Elliott Parable?
I said, I would have been.
Why?
I saw one in California.
I said, was it at the book fair?
He said, yes.
I said, how much was it?
And how complete was it?
He said, he thought it was lacking a couple of leaves, the title page and maybe some of the leaves.
I said, how much was it?
He said, he thought it was like $7,500 or $8,000.
I said,
simply inconceivable.
It is impermissible that an Elliott Bible went through the California Book Fair at eight grand and didn't get bought.
He says, it was there with the fair closed.
And... What was this thing?
Check out?
Wait, I couldn't believe me.
I couldn't believe it.
And I said, well, if you get it, I'm interested.
He called up the dealer.
He said it was being shipped back.
to him and have it, and I went through this whole bizarre world.
I'm surprised you didn't fly up to California.
Wait, you don't have to do things like that necessarily, but you're right, okay?
And back and forth, and it's more preposterous, more preposterous every day.
One day, the guy calls me and says, I got the book.
This is a book dealer in New York.
So I say, bring it up.
He says, I can't.
My car broke down.
I only had one car.
My wife was using it.
I'll come out.
No, don't come out.
And it goes on and on like this.
Two days later, he walks in and hands me the book.
He says, there it is.
And all of these thoughts that I had, I couldn't understand.
I mean, it certainly defied logic.
I couldn't understand this.
There's the book.
He says, look, it's lacking an extra page, which I didn't mind.
And I think I bought it for $9,000.
He paid $8,000, and I bought it for $9,000.
You got it?
Yeah, I bought it.
I got it.

and I am collecting, I have a collection of modern American fiction, I have a collection of Bibles, American Bibles, I have a collection, I have lots of areas, American bindings, which you saw, which is a very formidable collection, but those are collections from the basis of, I would say, almost accumulations.
